description: From Middle English baroun, from Old French baron, Medieval Latin barō, from Frankish *barō (“servant, man, warrior”), perhaps from Proto-Germanic *barô (“carrier, bearer”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰer- (“to bear”). Cognate with Old High German baro (“human being, man, freeman”), and perhaps to Old English beorn (“man, warrior”). Used in early Germanic law in the sense of "man, human being".

A Celtic origin has also been suggested, due to the occurrence of a Latin barones (“military official”) as early as the first century (Cornutus, On Persius' Fifth Satire). However, the OED takes this hypothetical Proto-Celtic *bar- (“hero”) to be a figment.

entries.meaning: The male ruler of a barony.
A male member of the lowest rank of English nobility (the equivalent rank in Scotland is lord).
examples: Coordinate terms: don, duke, earl, lord, prince, baronet

entries.meaning: (by extension) A person of great power in society, especially in business and politics.
examples: Synonyms: magnate, tycoon; see also Thesaurus:important person

entries.meaning: (UK, prison slang) A prisoner who gains power and influence by lending or selling goods such as tobacco.
examples: The first thing a baron does is to accumulate a supply of tobacco. He spends every penny he can earn on laying it in  […]

entries.meaning: A baron of beef, a cut made up of a double sirloin.
Any of various nymphalid butterflies of the genus Euthalia.

examples: baron and feme ― husband and wife
